title: Eldeco v. Charleston County School District
description: This appeal arises out of a contract dispute between Appellant Eldeco, Inc. and Respondents Charleston County School District and Skanska USA Building, Inc.  Eldeco alleged that Skanska breached the partiesâ€™ contract by failing to award certain electrical work in a new school building to Eldeco.  Eldeco also alleged that CCSD intentionally interfered in the contractual relationship between Eldeco and Skanska.  The trial court found in favor of Skanska and CCSD.  Eldeco appeals and we affirm.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Eldeco, Inc.,Â  Appellant,
v.
Charleston County School District, Mt. Pleasant Mechanical, Inc. and Beers Skanska, Inc. n/k/a Skanska USA Building,
Inc., Defendants,
Of Whom Charleston County School District and Beers Skanska, Inc. n/k/a Skanska USA Building, Inc. are Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal from Charleston County
Â J. C. Buddy Nicholson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26280
Heard January 31, 2007 - Filed March 5, 2007Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Frank M. Cisa, of Cisa & Dodds, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellant.
C. Mitchell Brown, of Columbia, Ryan A. Earhart, of Charleston, and Christopher J. Blake, of Raleigh, all of Nelson Mullins Riley & Scarborough, for Respondent Beers Skanska, Inc. n/k/a Skanska USA Building, Inc. Â 
H. Brewton Hagood, of Rosen Rosen & Hagood, of Charleston for Respondent Charleston County School District.
      
    
  


 CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL: This appeal arises out of a contract dispute between Appellant Eldeco, Inc. (â€œEldecoâ€) and Respondents Charleston County School District (â€œCCSDâ€) and Skanska USA Building, Inc. (â€œSkanskaâ€)[1].Â  Eldeco alleged that Skanska breached the partiesâ€™ contract by failing to award certain electrical work in a new school building to Eldeco.Â  Eldeco also alleged that CCSD intentionally interfered in the contractual relationship between Eldeco and Skanska.Â  The trial court found in favor of Skanska and CCSD.Â  Eldeco appeals and we affirm.
Factual / Procedural Background
CCSD began construction of a new high school building (â€œthe Projectâ€) in Mt. Pleasant, South Carolina in 2002.Â  Skanska was the general contractor for the Project and hired Eldeco as an electrical subcontractor.Â  At the time the parties entered into their respective contracts, the Project called for the construction of the school building as specified in the contract documents, which included an unfinished area for vocational training.Â  
After construction of the Project began, CCSD decided to complete the vocational training area (â€œCulinary Arts Upfitâ€) and add additional classroom space on either side of the school building (â€œClassroom Additionsâ€).Â Â  CCSD asked Skanska to provide a pricing estimate for the Culinary Arts Upfit and the Classroom Additions.Â  As part of the pricing estimate, Skanska asked Eldeco to provide an estimate for the electrical work required for the Culinary Arts Upfit and the Classroom Additions.Â  Eldeco submitted an estimate of $442,000.00.Â  
Following the school boardâ€™s approval for the additional work, CCSD formally requested pricing from Skanska.Â  Skanska submitted its formal pricing quote which included Eldecoâ€™s official price for the Classroom Additions electrical work in the amount of $881,855.94.Â  CCSD objected to the adjusted price, and Eldeco eventually lowered the price to $720,000.00.Â  Eldeco also submitted a pricing quote for the Culinary Arts Upfit electrical work of $248,311.76.Â  At the request of CCSD, Skanska obtained pricing from another electrical contractor.Â  Mt. Pleasant Mechanical submitted a price for the Classroom Additions in the amount of $348,812.00 and for the Culinary Arts Upfit in the amount of $229,340.00.Â  Upon instructions from CCSD, Skanska subcontracted with Mt. Pleasant Mechanical to perform the additional electrical work.Â  
Eldeco filed suit against Mt. Pleasant Mechanical,[2] Skanska, and CCSD.Â  Eldeco sought recovery against Skanska for breach of contract on the basis of Skanskaâ€™s failure to award Eldeco the electrical work in the Classroom Additions and the Culinary Arts Upfit.[3]Â  Eldeco sought recovery against CCSD for tortious interference with contractual relations and intentional interference with prospective contractual relations.Â  As grounds for these claims, Eldeco alleged that CCSD interfered with Eldecoâ€™s contract with Skanska by instructing Skanska to hire Mt. Pleasant Mechanical, Inc. for the additional electrical work.Â  
A jury trial began in April 2005.Â  At the conclusion of Eldecoâ€™s case, the trial judge directed a verdict in favor of CCSD.Â  At the conclusion of all evidence, the trial judge denied Skanskaâ€™s motion for directed verdict.Â  At that point, the parties agreed to dismiss the jury and allow the trial court to determine whether the term â€œWorkâ€ as defined in the contract documents included the Classroom Additions and Culinary Arts Upfit.Â  According to their agreement, if the trial judge determined that the Classroom Additions and Culinary Arts Upfit were within the definition of â€œWork,â€ the trial court would award damages to Eldeco in the amount of $120,270.00.Â  However, if the additional work fell outside of the definition, no damages would be awarded. 
The trial court ultimately concluded that the definition of â€œWorkâ€ did not include the Classroom Additions and Culinary Arts Upfit.Â  Accordingly, no damages were awarded.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Eldeco appealed, and this Court certified the case from the court of appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â  Eldeco raises the following issues for review:

  
    
      I.
      Did the trial court err in finding the Classroom Additions and Culinary Arts Upfit were not included in the definition of â€œWorkâ€ as provided in the contract documents?
        
        
    
    
      II. 
       Did the trial court err in directing a verdict in favor of CCSD as to Eldecoâ€™s tort causes of action?
    
  


Law / Analysis
I.Â  Eldecoâ€™s Claim Against Skanska
Eldeco argues the trial court erred in finding the Classroom Additions and Culinary Arts Upfit were not included in the definition of â€œWorkâ€ as provided in the contract documents.Â  We disagree.
A cause of action for breach of contract seeking money damages is an action at law.Â 
South Carolina Fed. Sav. Bank v. Thornton-Crosby Dev. Co., Inc., 310 S.C. 232, 235, 423 S.E.2d 114, 116 (1992).Â  â€œIn an action at law, on appeal of a case tried without a jury, the findings of fact of the judge will not be disturbed upon appeal unless found to be without evidence which reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s findings.â€Â  Townes Assoc. Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â  
The contract between CCSD and Skanska provided:

1.1.3 THE WORK
The term â€œWorkâ€ means the construction and services required by the Contract Documents, whether completed or partially completed, and includes all other labor, materials, equipment and services provided or to be provided by the Contractor to fulfill the Contractorâ€™s obligations.Â  The Work may constitute the whole or a part of the Project. 
1.1.4 THE PROJECT
The Project is the total construction of which the Work performed under the Contract Documents may be the whole or a part and which may include construction by other Contractors and by the Ownerâ€™s own forces including persons or entities under separate contracts not administered by the Construction Manager. 
6.1.1 OWNERâ€™S RIGHT TO PERFORM CONSTRUCTION WITH OWN FORCES AND TO AWARD OTHER CONTRACTS
The Owner reserves the right to perform construction or operations related to the Project with the Ownerâ€™s own forces, which include persons or entities under separate contracts not administered by the Construction Manager.Â  The Owner further reserves the right to award other contracts in connection with other portions of the Project or other construction or operations on the site under Conditions of the Contract identical or substantially similar. . . . 

The subcontract between Skanska and Eldeco provided:

Article 1:Â  Subcontractor, as an independent contractor employed by Contractor, agrees to provide and to furnish all labor, materials, scaffolding, equipment, systems, machinery, tools, apparatus, transportation, shop drawings, samples and submittals necessary to provide, furnish and complete the following Work, all to be performed in connection with the above-described Project, and in accordance with the following: 
Article 2:Â  The Contract Documents for this Subcontract consist of this Agreement and any exhibits or attachments hereto, the Agreement between the Owner and Contractor for the above referenced Project, all conditions to the Agreement between the Owner and Contractor (General, Supplementary and any other Coditions), all Drawings, Specifications, and Contract Documents referenced in that Agreement, along with Addenda and modifications to that Agreement.Â  
With respect to its Work, Subcontractor agrees to be bound to the Contractor by all of the terms of the agreement between the Contractor and the Owner (except for the payment provisions) and the Contract documents thereto, and assumes toward the Contractor and the Owner all the obligations and responsibilities that the Contractor by those instruments assumes toward the Owner.Â  

In its order, the trial court found that the Classroom Additions and the Culinary Arts Upfit were not included in the definition of the â€œWorkâ€ as provided in Article 1 of Skanksaâ€™s subcontract with Eldeco or the definition of the â€œWorkâ€ as described in Paragraph 1.1.3 of Skanksaâ€™s contract with CCSD because the additional work was outside the scope of the contract documents.Â  
Eldeco argues that the trial courtâ€™s finding was unreasonable because the definition of â€œWorkâ€ included changes to the work pursuant to a â€œChange Orderâ€ or a â€œConstruction Change Directive.â€[4]Â  According to Eldeco, the Classroom Additions and the Culinary Arts Upfit were merely changes in the Work that should have occurred under a Change Order or Construction Change Directive.Â  In support of this contention, Eldeco focuses on the fact that it had performed some 109 Change Orders during the course of construction of the Project, and that the process used for the Classroom Additions and Culinary Arts Upfit was identical to the process used for the other Change Orders.Â  Additionally, Eldeco contends that it was entitled to do all electrical work on the Project which was initiated through a Change Order or Construction Change Directive and administered by the Construction Manager.Â  
Contrarily, Skanska contends that the trial courtâ€™s decision was reasonable in light of the evidence presented at trial.Â  First, Skanska contended that the contract documents delineated only the work that Skanska was required to complete and, in fact, did not provide a right or obligation for Skanska to perform work like the Classroom Additions and Culinary Arts Upfit which exceeded the scope of Skanskaâ€™s original contract as general contractor.Â  Second, Skanska argued that Paragraph 6.1.1 of their contract with CCSD specifically reserved the right of CCSD to use other contractors for the completion of the Project.Â  Finally, Skanska presented several witnesses who testified that the additional work was outside the scope of the contract.Â  
We find that the record contains sufficient evidence upon which the trial court could have found that the Classroom Additions and Culinary Arts Upfit were not included in the definition of â€œWork.â€Â  Article 1 of the subcontract between Skanska and Eldeco clearly defines the scope of Work according to the listed specifications, which do not include the Classroom Additions or the Culinary Arts Upfit as modified.Â  Bolstering the testimony of its witnesses, Skanska introduced Exhibits 22-24 which indicated that Skanska and CCSD utilized supplementary contracts, and not Change Orders, for the additional work.Â  Moreover, because the general contract between Skanska and CCSD provided that any agreement between the contractor and subcontractor was subject to the provisions of the general contract, Eldecoâ€™s subcontract with Skanska could not have expanded Eldecoâ€™s rights as to the Work on the Project. Â As Skanska demonstrated, this additional work was outside the scope of the general contract between Skanska and
CCSD.
Accordingly, the trial court did not err in finding the Classroom Additions and Culinary Arts Upfit were outside the scope of the definition of â€œWorkâ€ as provided in the contract documents.
II. Eldecoâ€™s Claims Against CCSD 
Eldeco argues the trial court erred in directing a verdict in favor of CCSD as to Eldecoâ€™s causes of action for tortious interference with contractual relations and intentional interference with prospective contractual relations because CCSD was entitled immunity under the South Carolina Tort Claims Act (â€œTort Claims Actâ€).Â  We agree that the trial court erroneously applied the Tort Claims Act. Â However, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s ruling because Eldecoâ€™s claims fail as a matter of law.Â Â Â Â  
A.Â  Immunity Based on an â€œIntent to Harmâ€
Eldeco contends that the trial court erred by finding that S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-60(17) (2005) provided immunity to CCSD for the claims of tortious interference with contractual relations and intentional interference with prospective contractual relations.Â  We agree.
In ruling on a motion for directed verdict, the trial court is required to view the evidence and the inferences that reasonably can be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the party opposing the motions. Â Steinke v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation, 336 S.C. 373, 386, 520 S.E.2d 142, 148 (1999).Â  This Court will reverse only where there is no evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s ruling or where the ruling was controlled by an error of law. Â Â Id.Â  
To establish a cause of action for tortious interference with contractual relations, a plaintiff must show:Â  1) the existence of a contract; 2) knowledge of the contract; 3) intentional procurement of its breach; 4) the absence of justification; and 5) resulting damages.Â  Kinard v. Crosby, 315 S.C. 237, 240, 433 S.E.2d 835, 837 (1993).Â  To establish a cause of action for intentional interference with prospective contractual relations, a plaintiff must show: 1) intentional interference with prospective contractual relations; 2) for an improper purpose or by improper methods; and 3) resulting in injury.Â  Crandall Corp. v. Navistar Int'l Transp. Corp., 302 S.C. 265, 266, 395 S.E.2d 179, 180 (1990).
The Tort Claims Act provides that â€œthe State, an agency, a political subdivision, and a governmental entity are liable for their torts in the same manner and to the same extent as a private individual under like circumstances, subject to the limitations upon liability and damages, and exemptions from liability and damages contained herein.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§15-78-40 (2005).Â  The provision containing the exceptions to the waiver of immunity provides in relevant part, â€œ[a] governmental entity is not liable for a loss resulting from . . . employee conduct outside the scope of his official duties or which
constitutes actual fraud, actual malice, intent to harm, or a crime involving moral turpitude.â€ Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§15-78-60 (17).
During the discussion of CCSDâ€™s directed verdict motion, the trial court found that â€œintentional procurementâ€ and â€œintentional interferenceâ€ necessarily involves an â€œintent to harm.â€ Â Eldeco asserted that it did not have to prove an â€œintent to harmâ€ to succeed on the merits of its claims against CCSD.Â  At the conclusion of arguments on the motion, the trial court directed a verdict in favor of CCSD, primarily based on Â§15-78-60 (17).Â Â  
We hold that this was error.Â  None of the elements required for either cause of action, as clearly shown above, include â€œintent to harm.â€Â  Although it is true that harm may result from an intentional interference with existing or prospective contractual relations, it is not necessary that the interfering party intend such harm.Â Â  Instead, it is only necessary that they intend to interfere with either an existing contract or intend to interfere with a prospective contract.[5]
Accordingly, the trial court erred in directing a verdict in favor of CCSD based on the â€œintent to harmâ€ exception to the waiver of immunity provided in the Tort Claims Act.
B.     The Merits of Eldecoâ€™s Claims Against CCSD 
CCSD argues as an additional sustaining ground that Eldecoâ€™s claims against CCSD fail as a matter of law.Â  CCSD argues that the claims against CCSD are inextricably tied to the disposition of Eldecoâ€™s claim against Skanska.Â  We agree.
An essential element to the cause of action for tortious interference with contractual relations requires the intentional procurement of the contractâ€™s breach.Â  Kinard, 315 S.C. at 240, 433 S.E.2d at 837. Â Where there is no breach of the contract, there can be no recovery.Â  First Union Mortg. Corp. v. Thomas, 317 S.C. 63, 73, 451 S.E.2d 907, 913 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  Furthermore, an essential element to the cause of action for intentional interference with prospective contractual relations requires that the interference be for an improper purpose or by improper methods.Â  â€œGenerally, there can be no finding of intentional interference with prospective contractual relations if there is no evidence to suggest any purpose or motive by the defendant other than the proper pursuit of its own contractual rights with a third party.â€ Southern Contracting, Inc. v. H.C. Brown Constr. Co., 317 S.C. 95, 102, 450 S.E.2d 602, 606 (Ct. App. 1994).
Because we affirm the trial courtâ€™s finding that the contract documents did not include the Classroom Additions and Culinary Arts Upfit in the definition of Work, we find that Skanska did not breach its contract with Eldeco. Â Eldeco did not have any contractual rights to perform the additional work on the Project.Â  In the absence of a breach of a contract, Eldeco cannot prove the required elements of its cause of action for tortious interference with contractual relations.Â  Additionally, we find that the contract between Skanska and CCSD preserved CCSDâ€™s right to conduct other Work on the Project with its own or other forces.Â  Therefore, CCSD acted in pursuit of its own contractual rights, and Eldeco cannot prevail on its claim against CCSD for intentional interference with prospective contractual relations.Â  
Accordingly, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s ruling in favor of CCSD based on the failure of Eldecoâ€™s claims as a matter of law.
Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s decision.

 MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.


[1] Skanska USA Building, Inc. was formerly known as Beers Skanska, Inc.
[2] Mt. Pleasant Mechanical, Inc. is not involved in this appeal. The company filed for bankruptcy protection and thus, the pending action was stayed.Â  
[3] Eldeco also sought recovery against Skanska for violation of the Unfair Trade Practices Act.Â  However, the trial court granted Skanskaâ€™s motion for Summary Judgment, and that ruling is not implicated in this appeal.
[4] Â Both a Change Order and a Construction Change Directive are defined in Article 7 of the contract between Skanska and CCSD.Â  Essentially, a Change Order is a written instrument which authorizes changes in the Work and is used when all parties are in agreement as to the terms of the changes in the Work.Â  A Construction Change Directive is a written instrument similar to a Change Order, however, this document is used in the absence of total agreement on the terms of the Change Order.Â  
[5] The concept of â€œintent to harmâ€ is analogous to the concept of â€œmalicious intent,â€ which courts have previously interjected into the analyses of claims for intentional interference with contractual relations and intentional interference with prospective contractual relations.Â  However, consideration of these concepts in this context is often an error, due in large part to the historical use of the term â€œmaliciousâ€ to describe the idea that the intent must generally be improper in some way.Â  Therefore, as modern courts have addressed these causes of action, the distorted notion of â€œmalicious intentâ€ has been removed, and the elements of these torts have been clarified as specifically requiring the intent to interfere for an improper purpose rather than a motive generally grounded in some sort of spite or ill-will towards the plaintiff. Â See 2 Dan B. Dobbs, The Law of Torts Â§ 446 (2001 & Supp. 2006); and Prosser and Keeton, The Law of Torts Â§Â§ 129-130 (5th ed. 1984).

title: State v. Thomas
description: This case involves the general authority of a trial judge to suspend a criminal sentence given pursuant to a statute that provides a minimum and maximum sentencing range.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Christopher Thomas, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Â Reginald I. Lloyd, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26281
Heard January 30, 2007 - Filed March 5, 2007Â 

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Deborah R.J. Shupe, all of Columbia, and Solicitor Barbara R. Morgan, of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:  Christopher Thomas (appellant) pled guilty to distribution of crack cocaine within a prohibited proximity of a school.Â  Appellant was sentenced to the minimum term of ten years as provided by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-445 (2002).Â  He now seeks a new sentencing hearing, claiming the circuit court judge erroneously declared that he had no power to suspend appellantâ€™s sentence because a minimum sentence was provided by statute.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS
Appellant was indicted for distribution of crack cocaine and distribution within one-half mile of a school.Â  The State dropped the distribution charge, and appellant pled guilty to the proximity charge.Â  After appellant was advised of his rights and the court accepted the guilty plea, appellant was sentenced to a ten year prison term, the minimum provided by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-445(B)(2).
Six days later, after timely notice, appellant appeared before the court seeking reconsideration of his sentence.Â  Family members testified on appellantâ€™s behalf, and appellant asked the court to consider suspending the sentence.Â  The judge refused, stating that because a minimum and maximum sentencing range was prescribed by Â§ 44-53-445(B)(2), he was powerless to suspend any portion of the minimum sentence.
ISSUE
Did the trial court abuse its discretion by refusing to reconsider appellantâ€™s sentence on the grounds that it had no authority to suspend a minimum sentence?
ANALYSIS
The general power to suspend sentences derives from S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-21-410 (1989).[1]Â  This power does not extend to offenses where the legislature has specifically mandated that no part of a sentence may be suspended.Â  State v. Johnson, 343 S.C. 693, 541 S.E.2d 855 (Ct. App. 2001); State v. Taub, 336 S.C. 310, 519 S.E.2d 797 (Ct. App. 1999); and State v. Tisdale, 321 S.C. 153, 467 S.E.2d 270 (Ct. App. 1996).
The criminal statute violated in this case, Â§ 44-53-445, requires the person found guilty â€œmust be fined not less than ten thousand dollars and imprisoned not less than ten nor more than fifteen years.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-445(B)(2).Â  However, unlike the statutes analyzed in Johnson, Taub, and Tisdale, Â§ 44-53-445 contains no provision prohibiting the suspension of a sentence imposed pursuant to the statute.
Appellant argues that because Â§ 44-53-445 does not specifically prohibit suspension of a sentence for distribution within proximity of a school, the circuit judge had the authority under Â§ 24-21-410 to suspend the minimum sentence.Â  We agree.
The cardinal rule of statutory construction is to ascertain and effectuate the intention of the legislature.Â  Howell v. U.S. Fidelity and Guar. Ins. Co., 370 S.C. 505, 636 S.E.2d 626 (2006).Â  However, statutes must be read as a whole, and sections which are part of the same general statutory scheme must be construed together and each one given effect, if reasonable.Â  Higgins v. State, 307 S.C. 446, 415 S.E.2d 799 (1992).Â  Penal statutes are to be construed strictly against the State and in favor of the defendant.Â  State v. Muldrow, 348 S.C. 264, 559 S.E.2d 847 (2002).
In numerous penal statutes, the legislature has included specific provisions to prohibit suspension, in whole or in part, of sentences to fines or imprisonment.[2]Â  Here, the omission of any such provision in the proximity statute, Â§ 44-53-445, indicates the legislature did not intend to limit the general authority to suspend sentences.Â  
The State contends that because the proximity statute is part of the same statutory scheme as Â§Â§ 44-53-370, -375, and -440,[3] the legislature also intended to preclude suspension of sentences imposed pursuant to Â§ 44-53-445.Â  We disagree.Â  The legislature expressly included these limiting provisions in similar drug offense statutes and chose not to limit the authority to suspend sentences in Â§ 44-53-445.Â  See Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 533 S.E.2d 578 (2000) (discussing the canon â€œexpressio unius est exclusio alterius,â€ or â€œto express or include one thing implies the exclusion of another,â€ and holding that the enumeration of exclusions from the operation of a statute indicates that the statute should apply to all cases not specifically excluded).
Finally, the State argues that Â§ 44-53-445 is a specific statute that prevails over Â§ 24-21-410, a general statute.Â  See Taub, supra, and Johnson, supra.Â  While we agree that Â§ 44-53-445 provides the sentencing parameters for distribution of crack cocaine within proximity of a school, the statute does not contain any provision regarding suspension of a sentence.Â  Thus, this case is distinguishable from Taub, Johnson, and Tisdale because no prohibition against suspending sentences imposed pursuant to Â§ 44-53-445 conflicts with the general authority provided by Â§ 24-21-410.
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s erroneous ruling that it had no authority to suspend the sentence provided by Â§ 44-53-445(B)(2) mandates vacation of the sentence imposed.Â  We therefore reverse and remand for
resentencing.
 REVERSED AND REMANDED.
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] â€œAfter conviction or plea for any offense, except a crime punishable by death or life imprisonment, the judge of a court of record with criminal jurisdiction at the time of sentence may suspend the imposition or the execution of a sentence and place the defendant on probation or may impose a fine and also place the defendant on probation. Probation is a form of clemency.â€
[2]  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 16-1-120 (increased sentences for repeat offenders); 16-3-625 (resisting arrest with a deadly weapon); 16-3-655 (criminal sexual conduct with a minor); 16-11-330 (robbery with a deadly weapon); 16-11-700 (dumping litter on private or public property); 16-15-395 (1st degree sexual exploitation of a minor); 16-15-405 (2nd degree sexual exploitation of a minor); 16-15-415 (promoting prostitution of a minor); 16-23-490 (possession of firearm or knife during commission of violent crime); 16-25-20 (criminal domestic violence); 16-25-65 (criminal domestic violence of high and aggravated nature); 17-25-125 (unlawful taking/receipt of property and malicious injury to property); 23-3-470 (failure to register as sex offender); 23-3-475 (registering as sex offender with false information); 44-41-36 (unlawful abortion on minor); 44-53-370 (Class A drug offenses); 44-53-375 (possession, manufacturing, and trafficking of certain controlled substances); 44-53-440 (distribution of certain controlled substances to persons under 18); 50-1-85 (use of firearm/archery in a criminally negligent manner while hunting); 50-1-125 (wildlife trafficking); 50-5-1105 (exceeding wildlife catch limits); 50-21-112 (driving watercraft while intoxicated); 50-21-113 (driving watercraft while intoxicated resulting in property damage or great bodily injury); 56-1-460 (driving automobile while license suspended or revoked); 56-5-2940 (DUI or DUAC); 56-5-2947 (child endangerment when violating driving statutes); and 56-5-6540 (seat belt violation).
[3] These three statutes deal with offenses involving the distribution, possession, and trafficking of controlled substances.Â  All three statutes specifically prohibit suspension of sentences.

title: Ard v. Catoe
description: In this post-conviction relief opinion from a death penalty case, the Court affirmed the PCR court's finding of ineffective assistance of trial counsel.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Joseph Lee Ard, Respondent,
v.
William D. Catoe, Commissioner, South Carolina Department of Corrections,
Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Lexington County
Â J. Ernest Kinard, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26282
Submitted September 20, 2006 - Filed March 5, 2007Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General Melody J. Brown, all of Columbia, for Petitioner.
William N. Nettles, of Sanders & Nettles, of Columbia, and Christopher Seeds, of New York, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE WALLER: We granted the Stateâ€™s petition for a writ of certiorari to review the grant of post-conviction relief (PCR) to respondent, Joseph Lee Ard, who was sentenced to death for killing his pregnant girlfriend, Madalyn Coffey, and their unborn son.Â  We affirm the PCR courtâ€™s grant of a new trial based on ineffective assistance of trial counsel.
FACTS
On April 23, 1993, at approximately 5:30 a.m., Coffey died from a single gunshot wound to her forehead. Â She was 17 years old and 35 weeks pregnant at the time; the viable fetus died from a lack of oxygen. Â There were no eyewitnesses to the shooting. Â Respondent was tried for two counts of murder.
During the guilt phase of trial, the State presented over 20 witnesses.Â  Witnesses for the State testified they heard respondent threaten to kill Coffey and that he told Coffey he wished she and the baby were dead. Â Respondentâ€™s friend, Jay Johns, testified that he was with respondent and Coffey in the trailer just before the shooting, but had gone outside â€œto get a beerâ€ when he heard â€œa pop.â€Â  Johns went back inside the trailer; when Johns asked respondent what happened, he said â€œI think I killed her.â€Â  Johns called 911, and respondent fled the scene.[1]Â  
SLED agent Joseph Powell testified for the State as an expert in gunshot residue analysis.Â  Two types of samples, alcohol swabs and scanning electron microscope (SEMS) tabs, had been taken from Coffeyâ€™s hands.Â  Powell stated that he first â€œran the swabs â€¦ to see if we could find any amount, any elevated elements of materials.Â  The elements we are looking for are materials call[ed] barium, antimony and lead.â€Â  Powell explained that these are the three elements which are found in gun primer residue.Â  Powell testified that after the initial test on the swabs was complete, â€œ[t]he values were not sufficient for a positive cause that there was gunshot residue, but there was an indication.â€Â  (Emphasis added).

In a PCR proceeding, the burden is on the applicant to prove the allegations in his application.Â  E.g., Bannister v. For the foregoing reasons, I would hold that the actions of neither trial counsel nor appellate counsel resulted in prejudice against Ard.Â  Accordingly, I would reverse the PCR courtâ€™s finding of ineffective assistance of counsel based on the failure of trial counsel to adequately investigate and challenge the gunshot residue.Â  I would also reverse the PCR courtâ€™s finding of ineffective assistance of counsel based on the failure of appellate counsel to raise the issue of the trial courtâ€™s dismissal of a juror on direct appeal.
BURNETT, J., concurs.

[1] Johns also testified that he told respondent he was going to call the police and asked respondent what he should tell them.Â  According to Johns, respondent replied: â€œTell them I did it and they will have to catch me.â€Â  On cross-examination, however, trial counsel referred to Johnsâ€™ written statement given to police on the date of the incident which did not include the phrase â€œthey will have to catch me.â€
[2]  However, when Powell was recalled by the State in reply, respondentâ€™s counsel did cross-examine him about how most of the gunshot residue would have been expelled through the end of the barrel of the gun.Â  Trial counsel also questioned Powell regarding the fact that samples from Coffeyâ€™s hands might not have been taken until after the body was moved to the hospital for the autopsy and that moving the body around might cause removal of the residue. 
[3] The gunshot residue analysis was performed by Powell in 1993.Â  Avery left SLED in 1995.Â  Prior to the April 1996 trial, respondentâ€™s counsel hired Avery as a consultant to re-examine the analysis which had been done by Powell and reviewed by Avery.
[4] These matters were also testified to on cross-examination by some of the Stateâ€™s witnesses.
[5] The Stateâ€™s firearms expert testified that the gun, a Charter Arms .44 caliber double action revolver, required only three to three and one quarter pounds of pressure on the trigger to cause the gun to fire when the gun was cocked. 
[6] One of the Stateâ€™s witnesses on cross-examination corroborated that when she saw respondent during this time in Atlanta, he was upset or sleeping.Â  One of respondentâ€™s witnesses, Jerry Logue, testified that while respondent was staying at his apartment these days in Atlanta, he was upset, crying, did not eat, and spent most of the time sleeping.
[7] Throughout the guilt phase, the defense consistently challenged, both on cross-examination of State witnesses and through defense witnesses, the manner in which evidence was collected and the processing of the crime scene.
[8] Ard was the first South Carolina case where feticide was used to support the death penalty.Â  This Court held that the Legislature intended to include a viable fetus as a â€œpersonâ€ or â€œchildâ€ as those terms are used in S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 16-3-20(C)(a)(9) & (10), the aggravating circumstances of murdering â€œtwo or more personsâ€ and â€œmurder of a child eleven years of age or under.â€
[9]  In addition, the PCR court granted respondent a new sentencing trial based on appellate counselâ€™s failure to raise on direct appeal an issue involving the trial courtâ€™s dismissal of a juror during the sentencing phase.Â  Because we affirm the PCR courtâ€™s grant of a new trial to determine guilt, we need not address the Stateâ€™s remaining issue related to sentencing. Â See Whiteside v. Cherokee County Sch. Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 340, 428 S.E.2d 886, 889 (1993) (appellate court need not address remaining issues when resolution of prior issue is dispositive).
[10] At his deposition, Powell specifically stated the following with regard to Coffeyâ€™s gunshot residue tests:

If this person had handled the gun, grabbed it in some way, done [sic] something to knock it away this could be consistent with it.Â  I have seen this happen where people have handled weapons.Â  Iâ€™ve seen chunky [i.e., non-round] particles and Iâ€™ve seen - this is well within the realm of possibility.

During his direct examination at the PCR hearing, Powell stated that under the â€œcurrent protocol,â€ the results would permit a finding of â€œmay be consistent with gunshot residue.â€Â  
[11] Powell specifically stated at the PCR hearing that if counsel had questioned him about the â€œinterestingâ€ particles, he would have testified as follows:Â  â€œâ€˜The report is reading as no gunshot residue detected, and that is my position, but there are some things here which if - can they come from a gun?Â  Yes.Â  But they may not be from a gun.â€™â€Â  Likewise, at the deposition, Powell stated that because there were two (non-round) particles found on Coffey with the required three elements, this â€œabsolutelyâ€ indicated - even in 1996, the time of trial - that a weapon was involved.Â  Regarding those two particles, Powell stated â€œ[t]hat is absolutely something which I do not find without usually a weapon.â€
[12]  Although counsel had filed discovery motions in March 1994, Duncan and Fullwood testified they received 1200 pages of documents on February 2, 1996.Â  When trial counsel received this discovery was approximately when they first were informed the trial would be in April 1996.Â  Counsel moved for a continuance in March 1996, but the trial court denied the motion.
[13] When asked if Avery was counselâ€™s first choice for a gunshot residue expert, Fullwood responded, â€œWell the thing was that there wasnâ€™t - We were under such time constraints there was no such thing as trying to make a choice about anything.â€
[14]  In Strickland, the United States Supreme Court explained that â€œ[p]revailing norms of practice as reflected in American Bar Association standards and the like â€¦ are guides to determiningâ€ whether counselâ€™s performance is reasonable.Â  Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. at 688.Â  More recently, the Supreme Court again clearly enunciated that the reasonableness of counselâ€™s conduct may be measured by the ABAâ€™s guidelines for capital defense.Â  Wiggins v. Smith, 539 U.S. 510, 524 (2003).Â  Additionally, â€œ[t]he ABA standards are not aspirational in the sense that they represent norms newly discovered after Strickland.Â  They are the same type of longstanding norms referred to in Strickland in 1984.â€Â  Hamblin v. Mitchell, 354 F.3d 482, 487 (6th Cir. 2003).
[15] We reject the dissentâ€™s suggestion that we are holding it was a lack of time which caused counselâ€™s unreasonable decision regarding the retention of Avery as respondentâ€™s gunshot residue expert.Â  Indeed, we agree with the dissent that counsel â€œexpeditiouslyâ€ retained an expert.Â  We disagree, however, with the dissentâ€™s view that this expert must be presumed to be an appropriate one.Â  Given his previous involvement in the case while employed with SLED, any presumption about his objectivity is untenable.Â Â  
[16] The Deputy Solicitor specifically argued in closing that the defense could not attack Powellâ€™s testimony â€œbecause their own expert, Mike Avery, was hired by the defense to review Mr. Powellâ€™s workâ€¦.Â  He found no fault with Joe Powellâ€™s findingsâ€¦.â€
[17]  The trial court instructed the jury that involuntary manslaughter is the â€œunlawful killing of another without malice, express or implied, by some act or omission constituting criminal negligence.Â  Criminal negligence is the reckless disregard of the safety of others.â€Â  The trial court further instructed the jury that if there was a reasonable doubt as to whether respondent was guilty of murder or manslaughter, then the jury must â€œgive him the benefit of the doubt and find him guilty of manslaughter.â€Â  During the guilt phase, there was much testimony about drug use and drug dealing by respondent and his acquaintances.Â  There was also testimony about how respondent carried a gun and that the gun was on the floor of the trailer before Coffey was shot.Â  Considering this evidence, we find the jury could have believed respondentâ€™s account and yet could have also decided that respondent recklessly disregarded the safety of his pregnant girlfriend and unborn son, therefore allowing the jury to return a verdict of involuntary manslaughter.
[18] The record shows that trial counsel received the Stateâ€™s gunshot residue results on February 2, 1996, and the underlying raw data on March 1, 1996.Â  The majority implies that the time between February 2, 1996, and April 15, 1996, when the trial was scheduled to begin, was insufficient for trial counsel to retain a qualified gunshot residue expert.Â  However, those in the legal profession are well aware that trial preparation does not occur in a perfect world.Â  In my view, we must presume Ardâ€™s trial counsel operated appropriately and expeditiously in retaining their expert because there is no evidence that the expert, a former supervisor in SLEDâ€™s trace evidence department, was biased or otherwise unqualified to perform an accurate evaluation of the Stateâ€™s results on such â€œshort notice.â€Â  
[19] Additionally, I note that in support of their conclusion that trial counsel were deficient, the majority cites extensively to American Bar Association (ABA) guidelines on the prevailing norms of practice. The majority justifies their reliance on ABA guidelines by pointing to an endorsement of ABA standards in Strickland v. Washington.Â  In my opinion, however, the Strickland court makes it clear that the ABA standards, although helpful, are â€œonly guidesâ€ for assessing reasonableness.Â  466 U.S. at 688.Â  In fact, the Strickland court cautions:Â  

Â No particular set of detailed rules for counselâ€™s conduct can satisfactorily take  account of the variety of circumstances faced by defense counsel or the range of legitimate decisions regarding how best to represent a criminal defendant. Any such set of rules would interfere with the constitutionally protected independence of counsel and restrict the wide latitude counsel must have in making tactical decisions. 

Strickland, 466 U.S. at 688-89.Â  This Court has never adopted the ABA guidelines as the standard for prevailing professional norms in South Carolina.Â  Therefore, in my view, â€œreasonablenessâ€ in the instant case is best assessed in the broader context suggested by Strickland.

title: Fici v. Koon
description: This case involves a contract for the sale of land that violates the Statute of Frauds and whether attorney's fees are recoverable under the contract.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Patricia Fici, Respondent/Petitioner,
v.
Karol Koon, Kerry Koon Stack, Century 21 Bob Capes Realtors, Inc., and Francis
Hipp,
Of whom
Karol Koon and Kerry Koon Stack are the, Petitioners/Respondents, 
And Century 21 Bob Capes Defendants,
Realtors, Inc., and Francis Hipp are the Respondents.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO
THE COURT OF APPEALS 

Appeal from Richland County
Joseph M. Strickland, Master-in-Equity

Opinion No. 26283
Heard January 31, 2007 - Filed March 12, 2007

AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART; AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Jean P. Derrick, of Lexington, for petitioners/respondents.
William E. Booth, III, of West Columbia, for respondent/petitioner.
      
    
  


JUSTICE MOORE:Â  Respondent/petitioner Patricia Fici (Buyer) brought this action against petitioners/respondents Karol Koon and Kerry Koon Stack (Sellers) seeking specific performance of a contract for the sale of land.Â  The master-in-equity found the contract violated the Statute of Frauds and was therefore unenforceable; he also denied Sellersâ€™ motion for attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Both parties appealed.Â  The Court of Appeals affirmed in an unpublished opinion.Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.Â  
FACTS
The pertinent facts are largely undisputed.Â  Sellers, who are sisters, jointly own fifty acres in Richland County.Â  At Buyerâ€™s request, real estate agent Francis Hipp (Agent) contacted Sellers about their listing for the sale of thirty of the fifty acres.Â  Agent acted as a dual agent for both Buyer and Sellers.[1]Â Â  
The parties signed a form contract dated February 27, 2001, for the sale of thirty acres at a price of $375,000 based on a rate of $12,500 per acre.Â  The contract lists the property to be sold as:Â  â€œlot 2, Polock Road, tax map # 052000102â€ in Irmo, Richland County.Â  This description actually refers to the entire fifty-acre parcel owned by Sellers.[2]Â  The contract specifies that the property conveyed will have â€œat least thirty acres,â€ that Sellers will have the property surveyed, and states: â€œpurchaser and seller to agree on location of property lines.â€Â  
On March 9, the parties met at the property site with a surveyor to determine where the property lines would be drawn.Â  On an existing plat from 1960, the surveyor roughed in boundary lines and Sellers and Buyer signed their names.Â  On the plat is written:Â  â€œSurvey to be performed week of March 12 by CTH Surveyors.â€Â  Buyer and Sellers all testified they did not consider this rough plat as representing the actual parcel to be conveyed.Â  
At this same meeting between the parties, there was some discussion of restrictions on the property, including a prohibition on subdividing, leasing, and the use of firearms.Â  After Sellers left, Buyer told Agent that she had been advised by her attorney that any restrictions would not be valid because they were not included in the contract.Â  Buyerâ€™s attorney subsequently contacted Agent and insisted that Sellers produce written restrictions.Â  Because Sellers did not have an attorney, they used samples of restrictions supplied by Agent to draw up written restrictions.Â  These restrictions applied to the entire fifty-acre parcel. 
Meanwhile, the surveyor drew up a plat and delivered it to Agent on March 14.Â  Sellers did not approve this plat.Â  The surveyor delivered a second plat on March 20.Â  The plat indicates three tracts:Â  one in each of Sellersâ€™ names individually, and the third in their names jointly.Â  Agent recorded this plat on March 21 along with the written restrictions because the surveyor told him a plat had to be filed in order to file any restrictive covenants.Â  Buyer subsequently signed this plat indicating â€œproperty lines for tract 3 are OK with me.â€Â  Sellers, however, never signed this plat.Â  Sellers and Agent testified that Sellers were not satisfied with the property lines on either plat prepared by the surveyor.Â  
Buyer, in turn, was unhappy with Sellersâ€™ written restrictions and wanted to compromise on new restrictions which Sellers refused to do.Â  At the scheduled closing on March 30, Sellers appeared but refused to proceed.Â  
Buyer subsequently brought this action.Â  The master denied Buyerâ€™s request for specific performance of the contract finding the conveyance was unenforceable under the Statute of Frauds. Â Further, he denied Sellersâ€™ request for attorneyâ€™s fees. Â The Court of Appeals affirmed.Â  
ISSUES

1. Is the conveyance enforceable?
2. Are Sellers entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees under the contract?

DISCUSSION
BUYERâ€™S APPEAL
Statute of Frauds
The Statute of Frauds, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 32-3-10 (1991), provides in pertinent part: 

Â§ 32-3-10.Â  Agreements required to be in writing and signed. 
No action shall be brought whereby:
  
. . .
  
(4) To charge any person upon any contract or sale of lands, tenements or hereditaments or any interest in or concerning them; 
  
. . .
  
Unless the agreement upon which such action shall be brought or some memorandum or note thereof shall be in writing and signed by the party to be charged therewith or some person thereunto by him lawfully authorized.

To satisfy the Statute of Frauds, every essential element of the contract must be expressed in a writing signed by the party to be compelled.Â  Cash v. Maddox, 265 S.C. 480, 220 S.E.2d 121 (1975); Speed v. Speed, 213 S.C. 401, 49 S.E.2d 588 (1948).[3]Â  The burden of proof is on the party seeking to enforce the contract.Â  Cash, supra.
In the context of a land sale, a description of the property must be in a signed writing; parol evidence cannot supply this essential element.Â 
Jackson v. Frier, 118 S.C. 449, 110 S.E. 676 (1922); Hyde v. Cooper, 34 S.C. Eq. (13 Rich. Eq.) 250 (1867).Â  Parol evidence may be used only to explain terms appearing in the description;[4] the signed writings must contain a sufficient description of the land to show with reasonable certainty what is to be conveyed.Â Â  Cash, 265 S.C. at 484, 220 S.E.2d at 122.[5]Â  A description that does not include the location of the land or its boundaries is inadequate.Â  Humbert v. Brisbane, 25 S.C. 506 (1886).Â  Where there is no adequate description of which part of a parcel is to be conveyed, the conveyance is unenforceable.Â  Cash, supra; Cousar v. Shepherd-Will, Inc., 300 S.C. 366, 387 S.E.2d 723 (Ct. App. 1990).Â Â  
Here, the master considered two signed writingsâ€”the form contract signed February 27 and the 1960 plat with roughed-in property lines.Â  The form contract does not contain a description of the property to be conveyed except to specify that it is â€œat least thirty acres,â€ and indicates that Buyer and Sellers were to agree on property lines.Â  The 1960 plat, according to the testimony, was never intended to indicate the final boundaries but was to be the basis of the surveyorâ€™s plat.Â  The master, affirmed by the Court of Appeals, found these documents insufficient to satisfy the Statute of Frauds.Â  We agree.Â  A conveyance of land is unenforceable if the contract provides only that the boundaries are to be determined upon agreement to a subsequent survey and plat.Â  Hyde v. Cooper, supra.Â  The signed form contract dated February 27 is nothing more than an agreement to agree which is unenforceable under the Statute of Frauds.Â  
Buyer contends the master erred in failing to consider other documents surrounding the proposed sale which supply the required description of the land to be conveyed.Â  Buyer points to the surveyorâ€™s plat recorded with the written restrictions.Â  This plat divides the fifty-acre parcel into three tracts, two in Sellersâ€™ names individually and one jointly in both Sellersâ€™ names.Â  The plat itself is not signed by Sellers.Â  Sellers did sign the restrictions filed with the plat, but these restrictions apply to the entire fifty acres and do notÂ  indicate Sellersâ€™ assent to the property lines within the fifty-acre parcel for purposes of the sale to Buyer.Â  In fact, the undisputed testimony indicates Sellers were never satisfied with the plats prepared by the surveyor.Â  Buyer also points to a hold-harmless agreement with Richland County acknowledging that the county had no responsibility for maintaining the access road on the property.Â  This document was signed by the parties in contemplation of dividing the property.Â  It does not, however, include any description of individual tracts but refers only to the entire fifty-acre parcel. Â 
The Statute of Frauds requires that the agreement to be enforced must contain a writing, signed by Sellers, with a description of the property to be conveyed.Â  The documents Buyer points to do not satisfy this requirement.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the denial of specific performance.Â  In light of our disposition on this issue, we need not address Buyerâ€™s remaining issues.
SELLERSâ€™ APPEAL
Attorneyâ€™s fees

Sellers contend they are entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees as the prevailing party under the contract.Â  The contract provides:
  
19.Â  DEFAULTÂ  . . . . Upon default by the Seller, the Purchaser shall have the option of suing for damages or specific performance, or rescinding the Contract. . . . In any action to enforce the provisions of this Contract, the prevailing party and Broker(s) shall be entitled to the award of their costs, including reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees.
  

(underscore added).Â  
The master denied Sellersâ€™ request for attorneyâ€™s fees under this provision based on his finding that the contract was unenforceable.Â  The Court of Appeals affirmed, holding it was impossible for either party to default under the unenforceable contract and therefore attorneyâ€™s fees were properly denied.Â  We find this analysis incorrect because the contract is not void in its entirety.
First, paragraph 19 of the contract provides that if Sellers default, Buyer may bring an action to enforce the contract or may rescind it.Â  Here, Buyer chose to bring an action to enforce the contract and it was her burden to prove a default.Â  The attorneyâ€™s fee provision, which applies â€œ[i]n any action to enforce the provisions of this Contract,â€ awards fees to the prevailing party.Â  Sellers successfully proved there was no default since the conveyance is unenforceable.Â  Under the terms of the contract, Sellers are entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees as the prevailing party.
The Statute of Frauds does not affect the validity of the attorneyâ€™s fee provision but is simply a defense to the conveyance.Â  See Duckett v. Pool, 33 S.C. 238, 11 S.E. 690, 689-91 (1890) (a contract violating the Statute of Frauds is â€œneither void nor voidable . . . the validity of the contract is not affected but simply the right of action to enforce it.â€); Hillhouse v. Jennings, 60 S.C. 392, 38 S.E. 596 (1901).Â  The Statute of Frauds is an affirmative defense.Â  See Rule 8(c), SCRCP.Â  As with any affirmative defense, the party successfully asserting it is a prevailing party and therefore entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees where provided by contract.Â  Accord Dickinson, Inc. v. Balcor Income Props. Ltd., 745 P.2d 1120 (Kan. App. 1988) (enforcing attorneyâ€™s fee provision after finding other provision of agreement unenforceable under Statute of Frauds).Â  
Sellers submitted proof of $43,483.28 in attorneyâ€™s fees they incurred in defending Buyerâ€™s action.Â  At the proceeding below, Buyer stipulated that this amount of attorneyâ€™s fees claimed by Sellers under the contract is reasonable.Â  Accordingly, we reverse the Court of Appeals and remand to the master for entry of judgment for attorneyâ€™s fees in this amount.
In addition, Sellers contend they are entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees from the bond posted under the terms of a temporary injunction dissolved by the master in his final order on the merits.Â  The circuit court issued a temporary injunction prohibiting Sellers from conveying the property and charging them with maintaining it.Â  As part of this order, the court required that Buyer maintain a bank account with the amount of the net sale proceedsÂ  ($325,335) as security during the pendency of the action.Â  The order states that â€œsuch an arrangement will be adequate to protect [Sellers] for the payment of any costs or damages incurred by them as a result of the imposition of the Temporary Injunction.â€[6]Â  Sellers claim they are entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees from this security bond as â€œcosts or damagesâ€ caused by the temporary injunction.Â  Further, they contend the master should have held Buyer in contempt for closing this account before the resolution of post-trial motions.
Fees paid for defending an action to which the injunction is merely ancillary are not recoverable from the security bond.Â 
Walker v. Oswald, 181 S.C. 278, 186 S.E. 916, 919 (1936); Livingston v. Exum, 19 S.C. 223 (1883).Â  In an action to determine the rights of parties in reference to land, as here, an injunction is considered ancillary.Â  Hill v. Thomas, 19 S.C. 230 (1883).Â  Attorneyâ€™s fees for successfully ending the temporary injunction as part of this suit are therefore not recoverable under the injunction security bond.Â  Since Sellers are not entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees from this security bond, there is no harm from Buyerâ€™s closing of the account.Â  Accordingly, we find the contempt issue moot.Â  SeeÂ  Sloan v. Friends of Hunley, Inc., 369 S.C. 20, 630 S.E.2d 474 (2006) (case is moot where a judgment rendered by the court will have no practical legal effect). 
In conclusion, we affirm the denial of specific performance, reverse the denial of attorneyâ€™s fees to Seller, and remand for entry of judgment in the stipulated amount of attorneyâ€™s fees.
AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART; AND REMANDED.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur. 

[1] Causes of action regarding Agent are not at issue in this appeal. 
[2] This is public information from the assessorâ€™s office online at http://www.richlandonline.com/services/assessorsearch/assessorsearch.asp. 
[3] A contemporaneous writing specifically identified in the signed writing qualifies as part of the signed agreement.Â  Hyde v. Cooper, infra.Â  
[4] For instance, where the signed writings referred to â€œthe house in which [the seller] resides,â€ parol evidence was admissible to identify the house since there was only one piece of property fitting that description.Â  Kennedy v. Gramling, 33 S.C. 367, 11 S.E. 1081 (1890).
[5] We note that Goodwin v. Hilton Head Co., 273 S.C. 758, 259 S.E.2d 611 (1979), is unclear on this issue.Â  There the buyer sent an offer, including a description of the property, with a check.Â  The seller deposited the check and then had the property surveyed and sent a copy of the plat to the buyer.Â  The Court held, with no analysis, that the written documents satisfied the Statute of Frauds.Â  Presumably, the sellerâ€™s endorsement on the check attached to the offer was the signed writing that supported this conclusion.Â  To the extent Goodwin may be read to hold otherwise, it is overruled. Â Â 
[6] See Rule 65(c), SCRCP, (no temporary injunction shall issue except upon security by the applicant, in such sum as the court deems proper, for the payment of costs and damages incurred by any party wrongfully enjoined).

title: Edwards v. State
description: In this PCR case, the Court found the plea court had subject matter jurisdiction and reversed the PCR courtâ€™s grant of relief to Respondent.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Erasmus Edwards, Respondent,
v.
State of South Carolina, Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Richland County
Â Alison Renee Lee, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26284Â Â 
Submitted February 14, 2007 - Filed March 12, 2007 

REVERSED


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Robert L. Brown, all of Columbia, for Petitioner.
Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  In this post-conviction relief (PCR) case, we granted the Stateâ€™s petition for writ of certiorari to review the grant of relief to Erasmus Edwards (Respondent). Â We reverse.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Respondent pleaded guilty to second offense trafficking in crack cocaine and third offense possession with intent to distribute (PWID) crack cocaine.Â  The plea judge sentenced Respondent to fifteen yearsâ€™ imprisonment for trafficking and fifteen years for PWID, to be served concurrently.[1]Â  No direct appeal was taken.Â  
Respondent filed this PCR application alleging the plea court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to sentence him for second offence trafficking and third offense PWID.Â  The PCR judge found the plea court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to sentence Respondent for second offense trafficking and third offense PWID because the indictments listed the statutory provisions for first offenses.Â  The PCR judge resentenced Respondent to ten yearsâ€™ imprisonment for first offense trafficking in crack cocaine and to fifteen years for first offense PWID crack cocaine.Â  
ISSUE

Did the PCR judge err in finding the plea court did not have subject matter jurisdiction to sentence Respondent for second offense trafficking in crack cocaine and third offense PWID crack cocaine?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
In a PCR proceeding, the applicant bears the burden of establishing that he is entitled to relief.Â  Caprood v. State, 338 S.C. 103, 109, 525 S.E.2d 514, 517 (2000).Â  This Court will uphold the findings of the PCR judge when there is any evidence of probative value to support them.Â  Id. at 109-10, 525 S.E.2d at 517.Â  This Court will reverse the PCR judgeâ€™s decision when it is controlled by an error of law.Â  Sheppard v. State, 357 S.C. 646, 651, 594 S.E.2d 462, 465 (2004).
LAW/ANALYSIS
The State argues the PCR judge erred in finding the plea court lacked subject matter. Â We agree. 
We address this issue in light of our decision in State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 610 S.E.2d 494 (2005).Â  In Gentry, we abandoned the view that, in criminal matters, the circuit court acquires subject matter jurisdiction to hear a particular case by way of a valid indictment.Â  363 S.C. at 101, 610 S.E.2d at 499.Â  â€œ[S]ubject matter jurisdiction is the power of a court to hear and determine cases of the general class to which the proceedings in question belong.â€Â  Id. at 100, 610 S.E.2d at 498.Â  Issues related to subject matter jurisdiction may be raised at any time.Â  Id. at 100, 610 S.E.2d at 498.Â Â  Â Â 
In contrast, an indictment is a notice document.Â  The primary purposes of an indictment are to put the defendant on notice of what he is called upon to answer, i.e., to apprise him of the elements of the offense and to allow him to decide whether to plead guilty or stand trial, and to enable the circuit court to know what judgment to pronounce if the defendant is convicted.Â  Id. at 102-03, 610 S.E.2d at 500; S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-19-20 (2003).Â  A defendant must challenge the sufficiency of an indictment before the jury is sworn.Â  Gentry, 363 S.C. at 101, 610 S.E.2d at 499; S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-19-90 (2003).Â  
In light of Gentry, Respondent raised an issue related to the sufficiency of the indictments in his PCR application, rather than an issue of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  The plea court, as a court of general sessions, had subject matter jurisdiction to accept Respondentâ€™s guilty pleas and to sentence Respondent as a subsequent offender.Â  Gentry, 363 S.C. at 101, 610 S.E.2d at 499; see also State v. Smalls, 364 S.C. 343, 346, 613 S.E.2d 754, 756 (2005) (finding the court of general sessions has subject matter jurisdiction to try criminal cases).Â  Accordingly, the PCR judge erred in finding the plea judge did not have subject matter jurisdiction to accept Respondentâ€™s guilty pleas and to sentence Respondent.Â  
CONCLUSION
We reverse the PCR judgeâ€™s grant of relief and uphold Respondentâ€™s convictions.Â  We need not address the Stateâ€™s remaining issue.Â  See Hagood v. Sommerville, 362 S.C. 191, 199, 607 S.E.2d 707, 711 (2005) (appellate court need not address remaining issues when resolution of prior issue is dispositive).

 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Respondent also pleaded guilty to PWID crack cocaine within proximity of a school and second offense possession of marijuana.Â  He was sentenced to ten yearsâ€™ imprisonment for PWID within proximity of a school and one year for possession of marijuana, to be served concurrently with his other sentences.Â  These guilty pleas are not at issue in this PCR action.
