text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Sherry H. Simpson, Respondent,
v.
MSA of Myrtle Beach, Inc. d/b/a Addy's Harbor Dodge, Daimler Chrysler Services NA, LLC, and
CrossCheck, Inc., Defendants,
of whom MSA of Myrtle Beach, Inc. d/b/a Addy's Harbor Dodge,
is the Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Horry County
Â B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26293
Heard November 1, 2006 - Filed March 26, 2007Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Joseph Gregory Studemeyer, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Lawrence Sidney Connor, IV, of Kelaher, Connell & Connor, of Surfside Beach, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  This case arises out of an arbitration clause in an automobile trade-in contract between an automobile dealership and a customer.Â  The automobile dealership filed a motion for protective order and/or to stay and to compel arbitration in response to the customerâ€™s civil action.Â  The trial court denied the dealershipâ€™s motion on the grounds that the arbitration clause was unconscionable.Â  This appeal followed. 
Factual/Procedural Background
Â Appellant MSA of Myrtle Beach, Inc d/b/a Addyâ€™s Harbor Dodge (â€œAddyâ€), a car dealership, and Respondent Sherry H. Simpson (â€œSimpsonâ€) entered into a contract whereby Simpson traded in her 2001 Toyota 4Runner for a new 2004 Dodge Caravan.Â  Directly above the signature line on the first page of the contract, the signee was instructed in bold to â€œSEE ADDITONAL TERMS AND CONDITIONS ON OPPOSITE PAGE.â€ Â The additional terms and conditions contained an arbitration clause stating the following:

10.Â Â Â Â  ARBITRATIONÂ  Any and all disputes, claims or controversies between Dealer and Customer or between any officers, directors, agents, employees, or assignees of Dealer and Customer arising out of or relating to:Â  (a) automobile warranty, workmanship, or repair; (b) the terms or enforceability of the sale, lease, or financing of any vehicle; (c)Â  any claim of breach of contract, misrepresentation, conversion, fraud, or unfair and deceptive trade practices against Dealer or any officers, directors, agents, employees, or assignees of Dealer; (d) any and all claims under any consumer protection statute; and (e) the validity and scope of this contract, shall be settled by binding arbitration in accordance with the Commercial Arbitration Rules of the American Arbitration Association.Â  The parties expressly waive all rights to trial by jury on such claims. Provided, however, that nothing in this contract shall require Dealer to submit to arbitration any claims by Dealer against customer for claim and delivery, repossession, injunctive relief, or monies owed by customer in connection with the purchase or lease of any vehicle and any claims by Dealer for these remedies shall not be stayed pending the outcome of arbitration.Â  The filing fees for arbitration shall be paid by the party initiating arbitration.Â  The arbitrator may allocate the other arbitration fees as he/she deems appropriate.Â  In addition to any discovery permitted by the Commercial Arbitration rules, any party may take one disposition [sic] of an opposing party.Â  The parties agree to exchange all exhibits to be used in arbitration 7 days before arbitration.Â  The arbitrator shall determine the controversy in accordance with the terms of this contract between the parties and shall not consider any parole evidence which purports to alter, modify, vary, add to, or contradict such contract.Â  The arbitrator shall give effect to all applicable statutes of limitation.Â  Any arbitration under this agreement shall take place in Horry County, South Carolina and Customer agrees that the courts of Horry County , South Carolina shall have exclusive jurisdiction over enforcement of this contract and any award made by any arbitrator pursuant to this contract.Â  In no event shall the arbitrator be authorized to award punitive, exemplary, double, or treble damages (or any other damages which are punitive in nature or effect) against either party.Â  Unless otherwise agreed in writing, no claims against Dealer shall be consolidated with other claims in the nature of a class action.

Six months later, Simpson filed a complaint in the Horry County court of common pleas alleging Addy violated the South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices Act and the South Carolina Manufacturers, Distributors, and Dealers Act by misrepresenting the trade-in value of the vehicle, artificially increasing the purchase price, and failing to provide all rebates promised.Â Â Â  Simpson sought damages consistent with the maximum statutory remedies permitted for violations of these statutes.
Addyâ€™s answer denied Simpsonâ€™s allegations and asserted that the contract between the parties contained an arbitration clause such that the matter should be stayed and that Simpsonâ€™s only remedy was to file for arbitration.Â  Addy contemporaneously filed a motion for protective order and/or to stay and compel arbitration.Â  Thereafter, Simpson filed a memorandum in opposition to Addyâ€™s motion alleging that the arbitration clause was unconscionable and unenforceable.Â  
At the motion hearing, the trial court ordered the parties to attempt mediation.Â  After the parties notified the trial court that mediation failed, the trial court issued an order denying Addyâ€™s motion on the grounds that the arbitration clause was unconscionable.Â  Addy filed this appeal.
Â The case was certified to this Court from the court of appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR, and Addy raises the following issues for review: 

  
    
      I.
       Did the lower court err in ruling that the arbitration clause was unenforceable without first submitting the issue of enforceability to arbitration?
        
        
    
    
      II.
       Did the lower court err in denying Addyâ€™s motion to stay the civil litigation pending arbitration?
    
  

Standard of Review 
Arbitrability determinations are subject to de novo review.Â  Wellman, Inc. v. Square D Co., 366 S.C. 61, 67, 620 S.E.2d 86, 89 (Ct. In the alternative to its argument that the arbitration clause is not unconscionable, Addy suggests that any provision found by this Court to be unconscionable may be severed from the clause and arbitration allowed to otherwise proceed.Â  In fact, it seems as though the â€œAdditional Terms and Conditionsâ€ section of the contract anticipated just such a scenario.Â  Paragraph fifteen (15) articulates a severability clause providing that:

[9] We acknowledge that in light of the state and federal policies favoring arbitration, many courts view severing the offending provision and otherwise proceeding with arbitration to be the preferred remedy for an unconscionable provision in an arbitration clause.Â  However, we find the present case is distinguishable from those cases prescribing severability such that the invalidation of the arbitration clause in its entirety is the more appropriate remedy.Â  
First, the arbitration clause in the contract between Simpson and Addy contained a total of three unconscionable provisions while arbitration clauses examined by courts prescribing severability generally contained only one offending provision.Â  See Kristian v. Comcast Corp., 446 F.3d 25 (1st Cir. 2006) (severing a provision in an arbitration clause that prohibited the award of treble damages); Safranek v. Copart, Inc., 379 F. Supp. 2d 927 (D. Ill. 2005) (severing a provision in an arbitration clause that violated Title VII by requiring each party to bear its own attorneyâ€™s fees and costs); Ex parte Celtic Life Ins. Co., 834 So. 2d 766 (Ala. 2002) (severing a provision in an arbitration clause that was void as a violation of public policy by prohibiting the award of punitive damages); Healthcomp Evaluation Servs. Corp., 817 So. 2d 1095 (severing a provision in an arbitration clause that violated state law by not permitting the parties to appeal or review an arbitration award).Â  But see Primerica Fin. Servs. v. Wise, 456 S.E.2d 631 (severing two provisions governing the eligibility of arbitrators and the judicial review of an arbitration).Â  Second, two of the provisions in this case were found unconscionable because the provisions contravened state and federal consumer protection law. The sheer magnitude of unconscionability present in a provision that prevents a party from vindicating the partyâ€™s statutory rights, along with the fact that such a grossly unconscionable provision occurred not once, but twice, requires that we give significant consideration to a remedy in this situation that best serves the interests of public policy.Â  See Graham Oil Co. v. ARCO Prods. Co., 43 F.3d 1244, 1249 (9th Cir. 1994) (noting that severance of illegal provisions is inappropriate when the entire arbitration clause represents an â€œintegrated scheme to contravene public policyâ€ (citations omitted)).
Accordingly, while this Court generally would encourage severability of an unconscionable provision, we do not view the arbitration agreement between Simpson and Addy to be a proper candidate for the application of this remedy.Â  See Ingle v. Circuit City Stores, Inc., 328 F.3d 1165, 1180 (9th Cir. 2003); (finding arbitration agreement wholly unenforceable because of an â€œinsidious patternâ€ of unconscionable provisions, and therefore â€œany earnest attempt to ameliorate the unconscionable aspects of [the] arbitration agreement would require [the] court to assume the role of contract author rather than interpreterâ€); In re Cotton Yarn Antitrust Litig., 406 F. Supp. 2d 585, 604 (M.D.N.C. 2005) (â€œ[W]here, as here, multiple provisions of the arbitration clauses are inconsistent with Plaintiffsâ€™ ability to effectively vindicate their statutory rights . . ., the Court finds that the better course of action in this case is to excise the arbitration clauses altogether.â€).Â Â

title: State v. Barlow and Gibson
description: These direct appeals from appellantsâ€™ probation revocations raise the issue of whether the trial court erred in allowing a non-attorney to present the case for revocation.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Gary Andrew Barlow, Appellant.
      
    
  

Appeal From Charleston County
Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
AND

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Charles David Gibson, Appellant.
      
    
  

Appeal From Spartanburg County
Gordon G. Cooper, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26294
Submitted March 21, 2007 - Filed March 26, 2007Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellants.
Teresa A. Knox, Tommy Evans, Jr., and J. Benjamin Aplin, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE WALLER:Â  These are direct appeals from appellantsâ€™ respective probation revocations.Â  Both cases raise the issue of whether the trial court erred in allowing a non-attorney to present the Stateâ€™s case for revocation.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
State v. Barlow
In January 2003, appellant Gary Andrew Barlow was convicted of strong arm robbery and sentenced to 15 yearsâ€™ imprisonment, suspended upon the service of three yearsâ€™ imprisonment and two years of probation.Â  He was released from custody in July 2004 and placed on probation.Â  In September 2004, he was permitted, pursuant to the Interstate Compact for the Supervision of Parolees and Probationers, to move to the State of Washington.Â  In 2005, he was arrested in Washington for violating probation and extradited to South Carolina.Â  South Carolina issued an arrest warrant for Barlow based on the probation violations committed in Washington which included, inter alia, submitting an adulterated urine test.Â  
At the probation revocation hearing, Barlow was represented by counsel; a probation agent appeared on behalf of the State.Â  In addition, a victimâ€™s advocate presented to the court Sherry Hambrick, the victim of the strong arm robbery who made statements regarding Barlowâ€™s crime against her.Â  The victimâ€™s advocate also directly addressed the trial court about the facts of the 2002 robbery.Â  The trial court found Barlow willfully violated probation and revoked three years on his sentence.Â  

State v. Gibson
In 2001, appellant Charles David Gibson pled guilty to criminal sexual conduct with a minor, second degree.Â  He was sentenced to 12 yearsâ€™ imprisonment, suspended with probation for five years.Â  In March 2004, Gibson signed a paper which expressly stated he was to have no contact with any minor children.Â  An arrest warrant for Gibson was issued in July 2004 based on several probation violations.Â  Significantly, Gibson was charged with failure to refrain from association with any person the probation agent has instructed him to avoid.Â  This allegation was based on Gibson having his two minor children at his residence on June 19 and 20, 2004.
At the probation revocation hearing, Gibson was represented by counsel; a probation agent appeared on behalf of the State.Â  The probation agent argued to the trial court that, as a sexual offender in counseling, Gibson should not have put himself in a situation where he was at risk to re-offend.Â  Primarily for that reason, the probation agent recommended that a portion of his suspended sentence be revoked.Â  The trial court found Gibson in violation of his probation and revoked two years of the original 12-year sentence.
ISSUE

Did the trial court err by allowing non-lawyers to present the probation revocation cases?

DISCUSSION
Appellants both argue the trial court erred because it allowed the State to present the probation revocation case through a non-lawyer, i.e. a probation agent and victimâ€™s advocate for Barlow, and a probation agent for Gibson.Â  We disagree.
By statute, a probation agent has the power to issue an arrest warrant charging a violation of conditions of supervision, as well as the power of arrest.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-21-280(B) (2007); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-21-450 (2007) (the trial court or the probation agent â€œmay issue or cause the issuing of a warrant and cause the defendant to be arrested for violating any of the conditions of probation.â€).Â  A probation agent must report any arrest to the trial court and submit a written report detailing how the probationer has violated his probation.Â  Id. Â§ 24-21-450.Â  The statute outlining the duties and powers of probation agents also specifies that in the performance of a probation agentâ€™s duties, he â€œis regarded as the official representative of the court, the department, and the board.â€Â  Id. Â§ 24-21-280(B) (emphasis added).
We have noted â€œthere is quite a difference between a criminal prosecution and a probation revocation hearing.â€Â  State v. Franks, 276 S.C. 636, 638, 281 S.E.2d 227, 228 (1981).Â  Although the underlying probation violations â€œmay themselves be criminal offenses, the probation revocation proceeding is not a criminal trial of those chargesâ€¦, but a more informal proceeding with respect to notice and proof of the alleged violations.â€Â  Id. (citations omitted); see also U.S. v. Davis, 151 F.3d 1304, 1307 (10th Cir. 1998) (â€œProbation revocation proceedings are not criminal proceedingsâ€).Â  Significantly, â€œ[n]o additional punishment is invokedâ€ when the trial court decides to revoke probation.
Â Franks, 276 S.C. at 638, 281 S.E.2d at 228.
Given the statutory powers given to probation agents, as well as the fact that a probation revocation hearing is not a formal criminal proceeding, we hold the trial court did not err in allowing the probation agent to â€œpresentâ€ these cases.Â  Clearly the statutes envision a close relationship between the sentencing court and the probation agent when there has been an allegation of probation violation.Â  See Â§Â§ 24-21-280, 24-21-450.Â  Moreover, we find no error in allowing the victimâ€™s advocate to address the trial court.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-1560 (2003) (victim has the right to attend and comment at post-conviction proceedings affecting probation).
Finally, as to appellantsâ€™ contention that the non-attorneysâ€™ activities in these cases amount to the unauthorized practice of law, we find their comments and/or reports to the trial court do not constitute the practice of law.Â  Cf. Leverette v. State, 546 S.E.2d 63 (Ga. Ct. App. 2001) (where the Georgia Court of Appeals found that a probation officerâ€™s filing of a petition seeking a probation revocation hearing did not constitute the unauthorized practice of law).Â  Both parties cite to In re Unauthorized Practice of Law Rules, 309 S.C. 304, 422 S.E.2d 123 (1992), wherein this Court reaffirmed the rule that police officers may prosecute traffic offenses in magistrate and municipal courts.Â  Because a probation revocation proceeding is not a criminal prosecution, however, we find In re Unauthorized Practice of Law Rules inapposite to the instant cases.Â  
Nonetheless, the underlying rationale for allowing a patrolman to act as prosecutor in limited circumstances lends support to why it is also permissible for a probation agent to participate in the probation revocation hearing.Â  In State ex rel. McLeod v. Seaborn, 270 S.C. 696, 244 S.E.2d 317 (1978), we stated as follows:

When the officers of the Highway Patrol present misdemeanor traffic violations in the magistratesâ€™ courtsâ€¦, they do so in their official capacities as law enforcement officers and employees of the State.Â  These officers do not hold themselves out to the public as attorneys,
and their activity in the magistratesâ€™ courts does not jeopardize the public by placing â€œincompetent and unlearned individuals in the practice of law.â€...Â  To the contrary, this activity renders an important service to the public by promoting the prompt and efficient administration of justice.

Id. at 698-99, 244 S.E.2d at 319 (citation omitted).Â  Similarly, when a probation agent presents a probation revocation case, the agent is acting in his official capacity and is not holding himself out to the public as an attorney. Â See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-21-280(B). Â Clearly, the agent â€œrenders an important service to the public by promoting the prompt and efficient administration of justice.â€Â  Seaborn, 270 S.C. at 699, 244 S.E.2d at 319. Â Thus, we reject appellantsâ€™ argument that the non-attorneysâ€™ actions in these cases amounted to the unauthorized practice of law.

Accordingly, appellantsâ€™ respective probation revocations are AFFIRMED.
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

title: Koon v. State
description: The sole issue on certiorari is whether Koon was improperly sentenced to LWOP based upon his 1986 second-degree burglary convictions.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Robert Holland Koon, Respondent,
v.
State of South Carolina, Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Cherokee County
Â J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26295
Submitted December 7, 2006 - Filed March 26, 2007Â 

REVERSED


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Molly R. Crum, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
Deputy Chief Attorney Wanda H. Carter, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, Robert Holland Koon, of Bishopville, for Respondents.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE WALLER:Â  We granted the stateâ€™s petition for a writ of certiorari to review the grant of Post-Conviction Relief (PCR) to Respondent, Robert Holland Koon.Â  The PCR court found Koon was improperly sentenced to life imprisonment without parole (LWOP). We reverse. 
FACTS
In May 1998, Koon was convicted of grand larceny and second degree burglary.Â  Based upon Koonâ€™s 1986 guilty plea to four counts of second-degree burglary, he was sentenced as a recidivist to LWOP.Â  His direct appeal was affirmed by the Court of Appeals.Â  State v. Koon, Op. No. 2000-UP-291 (Ct. App. April 18, 2000).[1]Â  His first application for PCR was dismissed after a hearing.Â  After Koonâ€™s first PCR hearing, but prior to dismissal of his application, we issued our opinion in State v. Gordon, 356 S.C. 143, 588 S.E. 2d 105 (2003).Â Â  Koon filed a second PCR application asserting that, pursuant to Gordon, his prior second-degree burglary crimes should have been treated as one crime for purposes of sentencing under the recidivist statute.Â Â  The PCR court agreed with Koon and vacated the LWOP sentence.
ISSUE
Did the PCR court err in holding Koon was improperly sentenced to LWOP based upon his 1986 second-degree burglary convictions?
DISCUSSION
In State v. Gordon, we addressed the interplay between S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45 and Â§ 17-25-50.Â Â  There, we recognized that Â§ 17-25-45 requires defendants who are convicted of three â€œmost seriousâ€ offenses[2] to be sentenced to LWOP, while Â§ 17-25-50 requires that for purposes of sentencing, â€œthe court shall treat as one offense any number of offenses which have been committed at times so closely connected in point of time that they may be considered as one offense, notwithstanding under the law they constitute separate and distinct offenses.â€Â  In Gordon, we overruled prior precedent[3] which had held Â§ 17-25-50 was inapplicable in a â€œthree strikes ruleâ€ analysis and held, instead, that Â§Â§ 17-25-45 and 17-25-50 must be construed together in determining whether crimes committed at points close in time qualify for a recidivist sentence.Â Â Â  
Koon contends that, under Gordon, he should not have been sentenced to LWOP.Â  We disagree.Â Â  Although Gordon stands for the proposition that two offenses committed closely in point of time should be considered as one for purposes of sentencing, Gordon did not establish a bright-line rule as to what constitutes â€œtwo offenses committed so closely in point of time.â€Â  We find the 1986 offenses committed here simply do not fall under Â§ 17-25-50.Â  
The cases which have found â€œone continuous course of conductâ€ under Â§ 17-25-50 have been cases in which, for example, the defendant had two convictions arising out of a single incident, see State v. Woody, 359 S.C. 1, 596 S.E.2d 907 (2004) (two previous armed robbery convictions stemmed from a single incident but involved two different victims: Woody robbed a convenience store and was convicted of armed robbery of both the storeâ€™s clerk and the store itself); or situations which involve crimes closely connected in point of time, State v. Gordon (where trafficking and conspiracy to traffic crack cocaine occurred within a one week period, the offenses were, although separate and distinct offenses for which Gordon was properly sentenced, â€œso closely connected in point of timeâ€ as to properly be treated as one offense for purposes of recidivist sentencing); or apply to a single, continuous crime spree, State v. Benjamin, 353 S.C. 441, 579 S.E.2d 289 (2003), overruled by State v. Gordon, infra (two armed robberies and murder committed within a four-hour period).Â  
Here, the second-degree burglaries which qualified Koon for sentencing as a recidivist were the March 13, 1986 nighttime burglary of the office of P&G Motors; the March 14, 1986 nighttime burglary of the office or dwelling of Bill Willard; and the March 28, 1986 nighttime burglary of Cudd-Lovelace insurance Company.Â  
We need not address whether the March 13th and March 14th crimes could or should have been treated as one for purposes of sentencing.Â  We find the March 28th burglary of a different building, in a different location, which occurred two weeks later, clearly constitutes a separate burglary.Â  Accordingly, Koon had, at the very least, two prior serious convictions such that the present conviction constituted his third, and he was therefore properly sentenced as a recidivist.Â  
 REVERSED.Â  
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Koon asserted at the Court of Appeals that the offenses were not â€œserious offensesâ€ which triggered the recidivist statute, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45 (C)(2)(b).Â  The Court of Appeals found three of the four offenses were â€œserious offenses.â€Â  In 2004, this Court vacated one of the four convictions, finding the indictment alleged only third-degree burglary, such that the trial court did not have subject matter jurisdiction to accept the plea to second-degree burglary.Â  Koon v. State, 358 S.C. 359, 595 S.E.2d 456 (2004).Â  However, our holding in Koon I has been overruled by State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 610 S.E.2d 494 (2005).Â  The PCR court did not consider the conviction which was vacated by this Court in Koon I.Â Â Â  
[2] Â Second-degree burglary under S.C.Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-312 (b) falls into this category.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45(C)(2).Â  
[3]Â  State v. Benjamin, 353 S.C. 441, 579 S.E.2d 289 (2003).

title: Custodio v. State
description: This case involves the question of whether the PCR court erred by finding defense counsel was not ineffective for failing to attempt to specifically enforce his plea agreement.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
James Custodio, Petitioner,
v.
State of South Carolina, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Richland County
Â B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26296
Submitted February 14, 2007 - Filed March 26, 2007

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
John D. Elliott, of Columbia, for petitioner.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Robert L. Brown, all of Columbia, for respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE MOORE:Â  Petitioner was charged with numerous counts of burglary and grand larceny in connection with a string of at least seventy-five burglaries in Richland and Kershaw Counties.[1]Â  He was identified as a suspect in the burglaries after an individual observed him throw a lockbox from the window of his car.Â  The lockbox had been stolen from a home the same day.Â  Petitioner pled guilty to three counts of second-degree burglary and two counts of grand larceny.Â  He was sentenced to an aggregate term of forty-five yearsâ€™ imprisonment for the burglaries and concurrent five year terms for the grand larcenies.Â  Defense counselâ€™s motion to reconsider the sentence was denied.Â  No direct appeal was filed.Â  Subsequently, petitionerâ€™s application for post-conviction relief (PCR) was denied.
FACTS
At the PCR hearing, petitioner testified he met with two members of the Richland County Sheriffâ€™s Department, and two assistant solicitors of the Richland County Solicitorâ€™s Office shortly after his arrest.Â  Petitioner testified that, at the meeting, they offered petitioner a fifteen-year cap on the sentence if he would cooperate and tell them what burglaries he was involved in and help them retrieve stolen property and have it returned to the rightful owners.Â  Petitioner stated that, after the meeting, he met with one of the assistant solicitors alone because he believed she would tell him the truth about the deal.Â  Petitioner testified he asked her how much jail time he would receive if he accepted the deal, and was told it would be five to seven years.Â  Petitioner testified he met with members of the Richland County Sheriffâ€™s Department the next day and told them he would accept the deal.Â  That day, the officers drove petitioner around and he showed them twelve to fifteen homes he had burglarized or attempted to burglarize.
Petitioner testified he was worried the plea agreement was not in writing and, during the time he was cooperating, he asked police officers about providing him with a written agreement.Â  Petitioner testified police told him the solicitorâ€™s office did not want to put the offer in writing.Â  However, petitioner testified he felt he was already obligated to help them, and one of the officers told him a written agreement was â€œâ€˜just more of a technical thing.Â  [The solicitorâ€™s office will] honor the deal as long as youâ€™ll do what you said you were going to do.â€™â€Â  During this time, petitioner was acting without benefit of counsel.
Petitioner testified that, after counsel was appointed, he told her about the agreement and that he wanted the State to honor the fifteen-year cap.Â  Petitioner claimed he continuously requested that counsel attempt to enforce the original agreement, but she advised him he had no right to enforce it.Â  Petitioner testified he did not know he was entitled to have his original plea agreement enforced, and, at the time of the plea, he did not realize the plea agreement was binding on the State.Â  He testified he felt that if he did not plead guilty, then he was going to receive a life sentence.Â  However, he stated he would not have pled had he realized he had a binding plea agreement.Â  Petitioner testified he did not want a new trial, but rather, he wanted the deal the State had promised him.
Counsel testified she was not appointed until after petitioner had cooperated with the police and the solicitorâ€™s office.Â  She testified she met with the two assistant solicitors, one of the investigators, and the sheriff, who all confirmed a meeting had occurred between petitioner, the sheriffâ€™s office, and the solicitorâ€™s office, wherein petitioner was told that, if he agreed to cooperate and return items he had stolen, â€œthe charges would be limited to nonviolent burglary second charges, and there would be a cap of a fifteen-year sentence, and everything would run concurrent.â€Â  Counsel testified that either immediately before or after she began representing petitioner, the Solicitor decided not to honor the agreement.Â  She noted the Solicitor had not been at the meeting between petitioner and his two assistant solicitors.
Counsel further testified that, when petitioner pled guilty, she did not believe he had the ability to force the State to honor the original plea agreement.Â  Counsel testified she was unaware of the existence of Reed v. Becka, 333 S.C. 676, 511 S.E.2d 396 (Ct. App. 1999), when she represented petitioner.Â  She stated, at the time she represented petitioner, she believed the only remedy would be to vacate the plea and proceed to trial.Â  She testified that, had she been aware of Reed, she would have raised it to the solicitor and the plea judge.
The PCR court ruled counsel was not deficient and that there was no agreement whereby petitioner would receive a cap of fifteen years in exchange for his cooperation.Â  The PCR court found the record accurately reflected all plea negotiations, and petitioner had a full understanding of the consequences of his plea and the charges against him.Â  The court further noted there was no testimony from the sheriffâ€™s office or the solicitorâ€™s office concerning this issue.Â  Therefore, the PCR court denied relief.
ISSUE

Did the PCR court err by finding defense counsel was not ineffective for failing to attempt to specifically enforce his plea agreement?

DISCUSSION
The burden is on the applicant in a post-conviction proceeding to prove the allegations in his application.Â  Butler v. State, 286 S.C. 441, 334 S.E.2d 813 (1985), cert. denied, 474 U.S. 1094 (1986).Â  To establish a claim of ineffective assistance of counsel, a PCR applicant must prove:Â  (1) that counsel failed to render reasonably effective assistance under prevailing professional norms; and (2) that the deficient performance prejudiced the applicantâ€™s case.Â  Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668 (1984).Â  On review, a PCR judgeâ€™s findings will be upheld if there is any
evidence of probative value sufficient to support them.Â  Cherry v. State, 300 S.C. 115, 386 S.E.2d 624 (1989).
The State argues and the PCR court found that a plea agreement between petitioner and the solicitorâ€™s office did not exist.Â  The PCR courtâ€™s finding is without any evidence of probative value sufficient to support a finding that a plea agreement did not exist.Â  See Holland v. State, 322 S.C. 111, 470 S.E.2d 378 (1996) (Court will not uphold PCR courtâ€™s findings when there is no probative evidence to support them).Â  Both petitioner and his plea counsel testified regarding the existence of the agreement.Â  Plea counsel specifically stated she met with the assistant solicitors and they confirmed that petitioner was told that if he agreed to cooperate and return items that he had stolen; there would be a fifteen-year cap on his sentence.Â  The only evidence presented was that an agreement in fact existed.Â  Therefore, the PCR court erred by finding a plea agreement did not exist.Â  Cf. Jackson v. State, 342 S.C. 95, 535 S.E.2d 926 (2000) (where there is no evidence contradicting or conflicting with petitionerâ€™s testimony, PCR court erred by finding petitionerâ€™s testimony on the issue was not credible).
Petitioner argues that plea counsel was ineffective for failing to seek specific performance of the original plea agreement.Â  Petitionerâ€™s argument is based on the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision in Reed v. Becka, 333 S.C. 676, 511 S.E.2d 396 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  In Reed, the solicitor made an oral offer, which Becka accepted, to allow Becka to plead to a lesser offense with a recommendation of probation.Â  However, after the State consulted with the victimâ€™s family, the State withdrew the plea offer.Â  The trial judge found the offer was a valid and enforceable contract and denied the Stateâ€™s motion to withdraw the offer.Â  The Court of Appeals reversed.
The Reed court stated that a defendant does not have a constitutional right to plea bargain, a trial judge is not required to accept a plea bargain, and that ordinarily a plea offer is nothing more than an offer until it is accepted by the defendant by entering a court-approved plea of guilty.Â  However, the Reed court found the general rule is subject to a detrimental reliance exception.
This exception is stated as:Â  Absent an actual plea of guilty, a defendant may enforce an oral plea agreement only upon a showing of detrimental reliance on a prosecutorial promise in plea bargaining.Â  Reed, 333 S.C. at 688, 511 S.E.2d at 402; see also State v. Peake, 345 S.C. 72, 545 S.E.2d 840 (Ct. App. 2001)[2] (enforcement of an agreement not to prosecute is subject to two conditions:Â  (1) the agent must be authorized to make the promise; and (2) the defendant must rely to his detriment on the promise).Â  Even if the agreement has not been finalized by the court, a defendantâ€™s detrimental reliance on a prosecutorial promise in plea bargaining may make a plea agreement binding.[3]Â  Reed, 333 S.C. at 688, 511 S.E.2d at 402-403.Â  For example, a defendant who provides beneficial information to law enforcement can be said to have relied to his detriment.Â  Id. at 689, 511 S.E.2d at 403.Â  The Reed court adopted the rule that the State may withdraw a plea bargain offer before a defendant pleads guilty, provided the defendant has not detrimentally relied on the offer.
The Court of Appeals properly adopted the detrimental reliance exception.[4]Â  The State may withdraw from a plea bargain arrangement at any time prior to, but not after, the actual entry of the guilty plea by defendant or any other change of position by
him constituting detrimental reliance upon the arrangement.Â  Detrimental reliance may be demonstrated where the defendant performed some part of the bargain; for example, where the defendant provides beneficial information to law enforcement.
We find the exception applies to petitionerâ€™s situation.Â  In reliance on an agreement offering him a fifteen-year cap, petitioner fully cooperated with law enforcement by informing them of a multitude of burglaries he committed and assisting in the return of over a half million dollars in stolen property.Â  Certainly, helping law enforcement solve several burglary crimes and assisting in the return of stolen property is beneficial information.[5]Â  See Reed, supra (defendant who provides beneficial information to law enforcement can be said to have relied to his detriment).Â  Petitioner relied on the plea offer to his detriment by taking the substantial step of cooperating with law enforcement, i.e. by performing some part of the bargain, before the Solicitor withdrew the plea offer.[6]Â  Accordingly, petitioner could have enforced the oral plea agreement.
Petitioner claims counsel rendered ineffective assistance by not having his plea agreement enforced.Â  To prove counsel ineffective when a guilty plea is challenged, petitioner must show that counselâ€™s performance was deficient and that, but for counselâ€™s errors, there is a reasonable probability a guilty plea would not have been entered.Â  Hill v. Lockhart, 474 U.S. 52 (1985); Jordan v. State, 297 S.C. 52, 374 S.E.2d 683 (1988).Â  A defendant who pleads guilty upon the advice of counsel may attack the voluntary and intelligent character of the guilty plea only by showing the advice he received from counsel was not within the range of competence demanded of attorneys in criminal cases.Â  Carter v. State, 329 S.C. 355, 495 S.E.2d 773 (1998).
Because petitioner could have enforced the plea agreement under the detrimental reliance exception and counsel failed to take this action, counsel failed to render reasonably effective assistance.Â  Accordingly, counsel was ineffective in failing to have the plea agreement enforced based on the detrimental reliance exception.Â  Cf. Jordan v. State, 297 S.C. 52, 374 S.E.2d 683 (1988) (counselâ€™s conduct fell below professional norms for not protecting Jordanâ€™s right to enforce the plea agreement, which had not been withdrawn, with the solicitorâ€™s office).
Further, counselâ€™s defective performance prejudiced petitioner.Â  Petitioner testified he felt as if he had to plead, even though the agreement had been withdrawn, because if he did not, then he would receive a life sentence if he went to trial.Â  He stated he would not have pled had he realized he had a binding plea agreement.Â  Accordingly, petitioner was prejudiced by counselâ€™s failure to have the plea agreement enforced.
The appropriate remedy is the specific performance of the plea agreement.Â  See State v. Sprouse, 355 S.C. 335, 585 S.E.2d 278 (2003) (specific performance of plea agreement is most efficient option because it eliminated need for new trial or plea hearings and granted parties nothing more and nothing less than the benefit for which they had bargained); Jordan v. State, supra (counsel ineffective for failing to withdraw guilty plea once prosecution reneged on plea bargain; remanded for either specific performance of the plea agreement and resentencing or for a new trial).Â  Accordingly, on remand, the solicitorâ€™s office cannot assert anything other than the promised plea agreement of a fifteen-year cap on petitionerâ€™s sentence.
Because we reverse the PCR court and remand this case for proceedings consistent with this opinion, it is unnecessary to address petitionerâ€™s remaining argument. Â See Whiteside v. Cherokee County Sch. Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 428 S.E.2d 886 (1993) (appellate court need not address remaining issue when resolution of prior issue is dispositive).Â  
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
 TOAL, C.J., WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1]Petitioner waived venue and pled guilty to the Kershaw burglaries in Richland County.
[2]Affâ€™d, State v. Peake, 353 S.C. 499, 579 S.E.2d 297 (2003). 
[3]In State v. Thrift, 312 S.C. 282, 440 S.E.2d 341 (1994), we held that all plea agreements must be on the record and must recite the scope, offenses, and individuals involved in the agreement.Â  Id.Â  Further, we noted that our review of a plea agreement is limited to those terms that are fully set forth in the record.Â  Id.Â  We concluded that neither the State nor the defendant will be able to enforce plea agreement terms which do not appear on the record before the trial judge who accepts the plea.Â  Id.; see also State v. Sprouse, 355 S.C. 335, 585 S.E.2d 278 (2003) (review of an oral plea agreement is limited to terms set forth in the record).Â  The Thrift decision, however, is not directly on point because, in the instant case, we have a plea agreement that was withdrawn by the solicitor.Â  The fact the agreement was oral does not prevent the possible enforcement of the agreement.
[4]See Annotation, Right of Prosecutor to Withdraw from Plea Bargain Prior to Entry of Plea, 16 A.L.R.4th 1089, Â§ 3(a) (1982) (noting at least twenty-four states have adopted the detrimental reliance exception); 5 Wayne R. LaFave, et. al, Criminal Procedure Â§ 21.2(f)Â  (2d. ed. 1999) (prevailing doctrine is that the State may withdraw from a plea bargain agreement at any time prior to, but not after, the actual entry of the guilty plea by the defendant or other action by him constituting detrimental reliance upon the agreement).
[5]Cf. State v. Whipple, 324 S.C. 43, 476 S.E.2d 683, cert. denied 519 U.S. 1045 (1996) (mere fact that a defendant chooses to reveal otherwise undiscoverable facts in the hope of securing a favorable plea agreement does not bind the State to accept the defendantâ€™s terms; a defendant may not attempt to create a firm commitment out of plea negotiations).
[6]While the assistant solicitors were involved in offering the plea agreement to petitioner, the Solicitor was bound by that plea offer.Â  See State v. Sprouse, 355 S.C. 335, 585 S.E.2d 278 (2003) (promise of one prosecutor in the office bound all prosecutors in the office).

The Supreme Court of South Carolina
In re: Amendments to Rule 403, SCACR.

ORDER

The Rule 403 Subcommittee of the Chief Justice’s Commission on   the Profession has proposed amendments to Rule 403, SCACR, which reduce the   number of trial experiences required, but insure that the qualifying experiences   are a valuable learning tool. The subcommittee has also proposed amendments to   the provisions of the rule addressing attorneys admitted in another state, and   law clerks and staff attorneys, to reflect the changes in the number of trial   experiences required and, in the provision addressing attorneys admitted in   another state, to clarify the manner in which proof of equivalent experience may   be provided. Finally, the subcommittee has proposed a new provision addressing   Judge Advocates.
Pursuant to Article V, § 4, of the South Carolina Constitution,   we hereby amend Rule 403, SCACR, as proposed by the Rule 403 Subcommittee of the   Chief Justice’s Commission on the Profession. These amendments shall be   effective immediately. All civil jury trial, criminal jury trial and family   court trial experiences completed under the rule before the date it was amended   will be credited as the equivalent, i.e., a civil jury trial, criminal jury   trial or family court trial experience, under the rule as amended; however, all   trial experiences completed on or after the date of this order must comply with   the rule as amended. The amended   rule is attached.
IT IS SO ORDERED.
